titleStmt.title: Wiliam H. Turner to James F. Robinson
CWG8576

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p:
To His Excellency James F Robinson
Govenror of Kentucky

Your petitioner William Turner, a free Man of Color, would respectfully represent to your Excellency that on the day of August 1862, he was tryed in the Police Court for the City of Frankfort on a charge of assault and battery on the person of one Henry Clark a free man of collor. His Honor Judge Graham upon the hearing of the proof in the case assessed a fine of fifty dollars against your petitioner.

Your petitioner would further represent that previous to and since the commission of the said offense he has conducted himself in a peaceful & orderly manner, & now respectfully asks that your Excellency will exercise Executive Clemency towards him, & remit So Much of Said fine as is not due & coming to the officers, --

Your petitioner would further represent that said fine has been respited for twelve months by his Excellency
Governor Magoffin, late Governor of Ky with a promise that he would remit it entirely in due time, which "Respite" is hereby exhibited to your Excellency --

Your petitioner would further represent that his character has been and now is that of an honest and law abiding citizen inhabitant of Frankfort -- He asks a remittal of this fine ^at the time^ out of a sense of Gratitutde to the gentlemen who went on his hand --
Willaim Turner states that he believes the statements contained in the foregoing petition are true
We ^the^ undersigned believe the facts stated in the foregoing petition are true and that William Turner's is an object ^case is one^ for the exercise of your Excellency's clemency.

A. C. Keenon
W A. Gaines
J A Richardson
W H Sneed Co atto
J HJ. Harlan
S. D. Morris
R U Blackburn
Tho S. Page
R A Athey
C. J. Clarke
F. A. Estep
E. S. Theobald
Ewd H Taylor
E P. Borrman
